Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Analysis of Electrical Oscillations in Anterior Pituitary Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a hybrid mathematical/experimental approach to the analysis of the behavior of hormone-secreting pituitary cells. We record a cell's electrical activity and use features of this to calibrate a mathematical model. This calibration is done with the aid of a graphics processing unit (GPU) for fast optimization of a fitness function that compares features of the model voltage trace to those of the experimental recording. Once calibrated, the model is used to make predictions about the effects of changes in biological parameters, such as the conductances of various types of ionic currents. These predictions are then tested on the same cell that was used to calibrate the model, using the dynamic clamp technique to inject a model-based ionic current into a real cell. To help with our understanding of the model, and thus to make more useful predictions, we use geometric singular perturbation methods to understand the basis for spiking and bursting patterns of electrical activity, and the parameter ranges where different types of activity occur.

The ultimate goal of mathematical models for biological systems is to generate hypotheses that can be tested in the lab. If the model is well calibrated, then testing a prediction made by the model is the best way to determine if our understanding of the biology that is reflected in the model is correct. In particular, if a test of a model prediction fails, then it means that something is wrong with our understanding of the biology that was the basis for the model. However, this is only true if the model is well calibrated, since a model that is correct in its formulation, but incorrect in its parameterization, can lead to incorrect predictions. This caveat is particularly important given the great degree of cell-to-cell heterogeneity that exists in many biological systems. For example, a cell may exhibit one type of pattern of activity, while a neighboring cell of the same type may exhibit a very different pattern of activity, reflecting differences in biological parameter values. In this project, we combine fast model calibration with the dynamic clamp technique to calibrate a model based on a single cell's activity, and then test predictions made by the model on the same cell, overcoming problems associated with cellular heterogeneity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our first major finding involves the dynamics underlying the electrical bursting activity of pituitary cells. These cells secrete hormones of various types that regulate the physiological state of the animal, including stress, reproduction, and development. Endocrine pituitary cells exhibit electrical activity, and this is the basis for hormone secretion. It has been established that secretion only occurs when the electrical pattern is in the form of a burst, and that there is little secretion evoked by single impulses. The type of bursting exhibited by pituitary cells, called "pseudo-plateau bursting", is quite different from that exhibited by neurons. The latter has been the focus of mathematical investigation for three decades. but the dynamics of pseudo-plateau bursting have been unexplored until recently. Our first major outcome is a complete mathematical decription of the dynamics of pseudo-plateau bursting. This provides a much better understanding of the phenomenon, and has led to predictions that we have tested in the laboratory.   

 

Our second major outcome is the development of methodology for employing fast parallel computations with the Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) to perform a sampling of model parameter space with the objective of characterizing the types of behavior that can be produced by a model and the behavioral transitions that can occur when target parameters are changed. The biological application is again the electrical activity of pituitary cells, and target parameters are the conductances of various types of ion channels that can be modulated by hormones. Thus, we address the question of how the cell's behavior can be expected to change when a conductance is increased or decreased, within the context of the entire population of cells. Pituitary cells are very heterogeneous, and it is important to take this into consideration when making model predictions. Our approach does this. This population-based approach is akin to genomics or metabolomics, and could thus be called "modelomics". Although we apply it to pituitary cells, a similar approach could be applied to any biomathematical model based on ordinary differential equations.

 

A third major outcome is a study of how cells can sense the frequency of a pulsatile input signal. This question comes up in many cellular systems, including the pituitary gland where gonadotroph cells are stimulated by pulses of input from hypothalamic neurons. The frequency of the input determines which of two hormones is secreted, and the amount that is secreted. We asked the question of how a cell could sense the input frequency if the total dose of the input were normalized, so that high-frequency input and low-frequency input deliver the same total dose. Using simple intracellular signaling motifs, we were able to determine robust conditions for which the cell would respond more strongly to high-frequency input, or for which it would have a greater response to low-frequency input. These results were then applied to some widely used signaling motifs. 

 

A fourth major outcome was a study of one of the most successful biomathematical models. The Hodgkin-Huxley model for neuronal electrical activity ushered in the era of modern neuroscience when it was published in 1952. It has been followed by numerous mathematical simplifications and analyses. It consists of a voltage variable, a positive feedback variable, and two negative feedback variables.
